resources.string: Wanderer above the Sea of Fog
Leonardo da Vinci\'s Mona Lisa (c. 1503–1519) is a half-length portrait, famous for its enigmatic subject\'s faint smile. It is considered an archetypal masterpiece of the Italian Renaissance.

Michelangelo\'s Creation of Adam (1508–1512), a fresco on the Sistine Chapel ceiling, depicts God giving life to Adam, the first man. It\'s celebrated for its dynamic composition and profound symbolism.
Girl with a Pearl Earring (c. 1665) is a captivating portrait known for its luminous use of light and the mysterious gaze of the girl. It\'s often called the "Mona Lisa of the North."
Hokusai\'s The Great Wave off Kanagawa (c. 1831) is a woodblock print from his Thirty-six Views of Mount Fuji series. Its dynamic composition and vivid colors capture the power and beauty of nature.
Liberty Leading the People (1830) commemorates the July Revolution in France. It depicts a woman personifying Liberty leading the people over barricades, holding the French flag high.
Napoleon Crossing the Alps (1801) portrays Napoleon Bonaparte on horseback, leading his army through the Alps. It\'s a heroic and idealized depiction of the French leader.
Nighthawks (1942) captures the loneliness and isolation of urban life. It depicts people in a late-night diner, bathed in the eerie glow of artificial light.

Vincent van Gogh\'s The Starry Night (1889) is a swirling, expressive depiction of the view from his asylum window in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence. It\'s known for its vibrant colors and dreamlike atmosphere.
Wanderer above the Sea of Fog (c. 1818) shows a man standing on a rocky precipice, gazing out at a vast landscape shrouded in fog. It\'s a powerful image of contemplation and the sublime.

Raja Ravi Varma\'s Hamsa Damayanti (1906) depicts a scene from the Hindu epic Mahabharata, where Princess Damayanti is visited by the swan messenger, Hamsa. It\'s known for its vibrant colors and detailed depiction of Indian attire and jewelry.
